title: Top Republican defends Trump: ‘There is nothing in that transcript that rises to impeachment’
text:
House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy on Thursday defended President Donald Trump and criticized the impeachment inquiry that was launched this week, as the California Republican echoed other top GOP lawmakers who have made dismissive remarks about the inquiry.

“There is nothing in that transcript that rises to impeachment,” McCarthy said, referring to a rough summary of a July phone call between Trump and his Ukrainian counterpart that shows the president pressed Ukraine’s leader to “look into” Democratic rival Joe Biden.

The top House Republican’s comments dovetail with what Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell reportedly said late Wednesday. Referring to the summary of Trump’s Ukraine call, the Kentucky Republican told Politico it is “laughable to think this is anywhere close to an impeachable offense.” But there also has been some degree of GOP concern about the Ukraine-related allegations, with Utah Sen. Mitt Romney tweeting that they are “troubling in the extreme.”

Related: Whistleblower alleges Trump White House moved records onto separate network

And see: Acting intelligence chief says whistleblower did ‘right thing’ with Trump complaint

McCarthy on Thursday also blasted House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, accusing her of opening the impeachment inquiry on Tuesday “without even seeing one word of evidence.” He described Pelosi’s impeachment effort as a move that’s preventing action on lowering drug prices and other matters.

“The Democrats are the ones who are playing politics with this. I do not care about politics anymore. I care about this country, I care about the fiber of who we are, and I care about the future,” said McCarthy, who was speaking at his weekly press conference.

Read more: Many legislative efforts in Washington ‘were already effectively dead,’ and impeachment push doesn’t change that, analyst says

Pelosi, for her part, talked tough in her own weekly press conference, deploying the word “cover-up” to characterize the alleged move by the White House to “lock down” information about the Ukraine call.
